dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful day in this neighborhood. A beautiful day for a neighbor. Would you be mine? Could you be mine? At the closet, Fred takes off his sport coat and hangs it

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It's a neighborly day in this beauty wood. A neighborly day for a beauty. Would you be mine? Could you be mine? He plucks a RED CARDIGAN off the hanger.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to have a neighbor just like you. Fred points right into the camera. You.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to live ina neighborhood with you. So, let's make the most of this beeeeautiful day. He playfully zips up the sweater before sitting on the be

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Since we're together we might as well say. Repeating a ritual he has done for decades, Fred slips of his DRESS SHOE and tosses it to his other hand.  He replaces it with the BLUE BOAT SHOE and ties it tight before moving on to the next foot.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Would you be mine, could you be mine? Won't you be my neighbor? Won't you please, won't you please? Please won't you be my neighbor? He smiles and settles in. Then, that soft warm voice.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello neighbor. So good to see you again today. Fred pulls out a large WOODEN BOARD checkered with severa little patterned DOORS.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you see the special thing that I brought in to show you? It’s called a picture board, because behind each one of these little doors is a picture of people. Look who this one is. Fred opens a door to reveal a soft-focus headshot of LADY ABERLIN, 40s.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Lady Aberlin. Let’s see who's behind this door. He opens another -- this time it’s the KING FRIDAY puppet

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s King Friday the thirteenth -- with his crown and mustache and beard. What’s behind here? Fred opens another door. It’s MISTER MCFEELY, 50s, in a w wig, goatee, and hat.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Mister McFeely. He says “speedy delivery,” doesn’t he? (then) Today, I’d like you to meet a new friend of mine named Lloyd Vogel. He opens the last door. It’s LLOYD VOGEL, 35. He’s got a BLOODY LIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has hurt my friend Lloyd, and not just on his face. He is having a hard time forgiving the person who hurt him. Do you know what it means, to forgive? Fred waits for you to answer.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is a decision we make to release a person from the feelings of anger we have at them. It’s strange, but sometimes it’s hardest of all to forgive someone we love. Fred smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s go say hello to my new friend Lloyd, shall we? Fred heads toward the front door, and waves for us to com along -- The VIBRAPHONE chimes carry us out the window and into --

dialogues.speaker: THE MINIATURE NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: The same houses, cars, trees, and trolley -- in reverse. We expand out to reveal much more than just Mister Rogers Neighborhood. Now we see all of --

dialogues.speaker: MINIATURE PITTSBURGH
dialogues.text: And we're over the bridges and rivers, past the Monongahe Incline, over the trees and mountains into --

dialogues.speaker: MINIATURE NEW YORK CITY
dialogues.text: We stop over NEW YORK CITY as the sun sets. The city lights flicker on, and the sounds of life in Manhattan bring us into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The historic art-deco masterpiece glows in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push into the third floor window. Inside --

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Here to present this year’s winner for Feature Writing, please welcome last year’s winner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish black-tie awards dinner, celebrating the NATIONA MAGAZINE AWARDS.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Lloyd Vogel. The GLAMOROUS CROWD of journalists applaud as Lloyd gets from his seat and approaches the podium. ELLEN, 50, his long-time editor, looks on.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Thank you. It’s so wonderful to be here tonight with my fellow misfits. We clean up good. Chuckles. Lloyd looks to the teleprompter, then --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why do we write for magazines for a living? Because doing anything else doesn’t seem quite like living at all. We get a front row seat to history. We get to expose the truth that others cannot see. And sometimes, just sometimes, we get to change a broken world with our words. APPLAUSE takes us to -- EXT. LLOYD’S BUILDING - STREET - LATE NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd exits a cab in front of his building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight fills the airy home. Lloyd’s wife, ANDREA, 35, t a huge bite of a brioche. She’s in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Lloyd places a handful of diapers on a pile of BABY CLOTH and GEAR. He’s trying to pack. GAVIN, their four-month-ol sleeps in the rocker nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. I needed this. I ate a block of cheese for dinner. Lloyd smiles, then looks at the disorganized pile of clot

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So what are we forgetting?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We definitely need more diapers.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: More than this? We’re just going to Jersey for one night.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We go through at least twelve a day.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: We do? What are you feeding that kid? Wouldn’t it be easier to just leave him with a sitter? We could --

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You know I’m not ready to leave him with a stranger. He’s too little.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Hey, so your sister called last night.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Uh huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted to make sure you’d written your toast.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m all set. I’m just gonna use my speech from her first wedding. Or maybe from her second.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (playing along) Okay sure. Just change the names. They share a smile. She’s suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And hey. She wanted me to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Your father is coming. Lloyd goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess she reached out months ago, and didn’t think he would respond but he called, and he’s coming to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You okay? Lloyd pulls it together.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah! Fine. (then, slightly jokey) But I don’t think we should go?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Lloyd!

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What? Seriously -- why have a baby if you can’t use him to get out social engagements?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s what Lorraine’s afraid of -- that you’1l back out.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I'm kidding. I would never miss her wedding. I look forward to them every year. Andrea laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Okay. Well I think it’1ll be nice for Gavin to meet his grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Sure. Lloyd is distracted. Andrea studies him, worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAXI CAB idles. Andrea bounces Gavin on the sidewalk. In the back of the car, Lloyd tries to install a baby sea Lloyd SHOVES the car seat HARD, seeping stress.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (to Gavin) Daddy’s just being funny. Lloyd gives the car seat a shake. It’s completely unattac

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Here. Take him. Here. Andrea offers Gavin to Lloyd. He takes the baby, and Andr climbs into the back seat. Lloyd bounces Gavin, looking off into space, not connecte Andrea jams her knee into the seat and CLICKS it into pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Great. The vibraphone takes us to --

dialogues.speaker: MINIATURE TRI-STATE AREA
dialogues.text: The NEW YORK SKYLINE and the HUDSON RIVER. We dip down toward I-95, where the TAXI moves North towar New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modest, sparsely attended affair. TODD, 35, the doughy and blue collar groom, waits by the A-REVEREND. Lloyd and Andrea sit near the back. Gavin is asleep on An in a carrier.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (re: Todd) He looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: He should be. He’s marrying Lorraine. The music changes. The small crowd STANDS and TURNS to see LORRAINE VOGEL, 3 in a slinky white dress. Escorting Lorraine is JERRY VOGEL, 65, tan with pomade in hair and a flashy blazer. Jerry waves at Lloyd -- a big ratpack grin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Breathe. Lloyd quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedding music blasts.  9. Lorraine and Todd approach Lloyd and Andrea at their tabl

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (to Lorraine) Oh my, you look so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I’m ten pounds short of my target weight, but whatever -- He notices Todd, the groom.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m Lloyd. The brother.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I know, man. I guess I’m Todd, you know, the husband. Todd swallows Lloyd in a bro-hug. Lorraine squeezes Gavin’s foot.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: And look at you, ya little peanut. (then) I don’t think we’re having kids. Lloyd notices Jerry on the other side of the room. He's talking to DOROTHY, 55, wearing heavy make-up and a low-c dress.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: How'd that happen?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I invited him and he came.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: To walk you down the aisle? Really?

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: He offered. He missed the first two, I thought ‘why the hell not?’

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I can think of a few reasons.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: He’s old, and if he’s gonna make an effort --  10. Jerry takes the mic at the stage. Lloyd’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, I guess it’s time we get this started. So, in lieu of the typical father of the bride speech, I thought I’d -- well, I'd like to sing a little ditty. The music starts.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one is for my Lorraine -- and for you too -- Jerry leans over to Dorothy, searching for his name, then

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Todd. Jerry sings “Somethin’ Stupid,” while Lorraine and Todd m to the center to slow dance. Jerry croons, doing his best Sinatra.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I know I stand in line until you think you have the time To spend an evening with me And if we go some place to dance, I know that there's a chance you will be leaving with me --

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Admit it. Now you regret eloping.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Of course he’s drunk.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: He can sing.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Then afterwards we drop into a quiet little place- And have a drink or two And then I go and spoil it all by saying something stupid Like “I love you” Jerry looks at Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I love you.  11. Then, he trains his eyes on Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd hides away in a corner with Andrea and Gavin. Jerry bounds up.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Here we are. In the pearl of the Garden State --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hello, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Come on! You don’t have to call me Jerry. Or call me Jerry. I don’t care. Jerry trains his grin on Andrea and Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And hello to you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Hi -- I’m Andrea. Lloyd’s wife.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Andrea! Of course! What a unique pleasure. (to Gavin) Hello, little fella.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: This is Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What a handsome man. You look just like me -- and Lloyd too, I guess, but mostly me. Andrea smiles. A very long, very awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What is that? A pop? That stuff’1ll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I'm giving my toast, then we’re leaving, so -- Jerry turns to Andrea.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Doll -- could you give us a moment?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: She’s not a doll. She’s a public interest attorney.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: There money in that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We’re gonna circulate. Lloyd gives Andrea a hard look. Andrea mouths “breathe.”

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You got a BABY. And a wife? Lloyd nods. Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You happy?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m happy.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Well, she seems nice enough. (then) But aren’t you kinda old to have a baby --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m not that old.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You're smart. Your mom and I hardly knew each other when she got pregnant. We were babies.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Don’t talk about her.  13. Jerry grabs Lloyd’s arm tightly. Lloyd tenses at the constraint.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You don’t know the whole story. Your mom didn’t exactly- Lloyd pulls himself away, and decks Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: DON’T TALK ABOUT MY MOM. Todd grabs Lloyd before he can lunge at Jerry again.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa!

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Let go of me. Lloyd shoves Todd hard. He SLAMS into Lorraine, spilling wine all over her dress.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop it! In the commotion, a GROOMSMAN comes out of nowhere and DE Lloyd. Suddenly, everyone is scrapping. Dorothy runs in.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: What the hell!! Jerry tries to break them up, and gets pushed back, knock him against the windows. Blood dumps out onto Lloyd’s chin. Everything stops. Lloyd looks around the room. Silence. Lloyd's eyes land on Andrea, in disbelief. Gavin’s scream

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrea and Lloyd are mid-argument. Lloyd holds a bloody b towel to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shoulda known this would happen.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t inevitable! It wasn’t like “oh, when these two see each other, somebody's going to get punched.”

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You didn’t hear him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You were out of control.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: He was out of control!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: So you’re going to take no responsibility for what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Of course I am. I offered to pay for Lorraine’s dry cleaning. Andrea stares at him in disbelief. 14. The VIBRAPHONE floats in with the melody of “What Do You With The Mad That You Feel” -- We FREEZE and PUSH IN on Lloyd’s face -- his broken nose, swollen eye and split lip.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. MISTER ROGERS’ NEIGHBORHOOD HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull out on the photo of that same face. Fred sits beside the big Wooden Board with little pattern doors. He stares at Lloyd’s photo.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Have you ever felt like Lloyd does? So angry you want to hurt someone else, or yourself? I know I have. Fred smiles.  15.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was a boy I was very chubby. The other kids would chase me and call me names -- like “Fat Freddy.” It made me very sad and I would cry to myself. And other times, it made me very angry. (then) There is always something to do with the mad you feel. There’s a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? Another knock.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Someone is at my door. Let’s go see who it is. Fred looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Mr. McFeely. He opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: Speedy Delivery. Mr. McFeely hands Fred the mail.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. It’s a magazine. In the bundle -- an ESQUIRE MAGAZINE. He picks it up, lea through it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. Magazines are always filled with all sorts of interesting information.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: They sure are.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: My friend Lloyd works for a magazine. He’s a very wonderful writer.  16.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: That reminds me. I have a video I found, and I thought you and your neighbor may like to see it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: It’s about how people make a magazine. It’s called “How People Make a Magazine.” I know a lot of people like magazines so I thought you might find this interesting.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I think we would -- do you have time to show it to us now?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to see it again.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Let’s look at it on Picture Picture. Mr. McFeely takes the video out of the sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY
dialogues.text: Here’s the tape. Fred takes the tape and slides it in the wall by the painting.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We'll watch it on Picture Picture and see how people make a magazine. In the painting, a large scale PRINTING FACILITY. We push INTO the frame --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TECHNICIAN globs yellow ink onto a roller.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now this is the ink they use in the printing press that prints the magazines.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yellow ink. It looks like mustard.  17. A forklift moves a giant roll of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And these are large rolls of blank paper that will get loaded into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wonder how many magazines they can make out of one of those large rolls. The PRINTING PRESS whirs to life. The belt spits out an image in blue, then yellow, then gr then red.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They print the magazines in giant sheets. One color at a time. The pages are sorted, collated, and stapled, and then --

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This machine assembles the magazine and glues it all together. The finished magazine flies out. The cover of ESQUIRE MAGAZINE. Now we're in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slick and bustling. Magazine culture in its 90’s heyday. An EMPLOYEE weaves through cubicles, distributing the new issue to every desk.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, now who’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These are the people who decide what will be in the magazine. They pick the pictures and design the layout.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s an important job.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCFEELY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And these are the people who write the words that go into a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It is a lot of work to make a magazine, isn’t it? Lloyd enters the bullpen. His lip is still swollen and hi black eye looks worse. He beelines for a corner office. INT. ESQUIRE MAGAZINE - ELLEN’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd enters, all smiles. From her desk, Ellen sees Lloyd’s busted nose and raises eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Pay no attention to my face. Softball injury. Nothing to worry about. Good morning, Ellen. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: This should be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What should?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Sending you on an assignment with a busted face.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: An assignment?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yep. You’re the perfect person for it. You just had a baby.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Why are you giving me an assignment?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: We're doing an issue on heroes. We're profiling a number of inspirational people -- we just need a small piece of copy to accompany a pretty photo.  19.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You hired me as an investigative journalist, Ellen. I don’t do puff pieces. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Wait a second, didn’t I hire you to do whatever I tell you to do? And right now that’s doing a profile on one of our nation’s heroes.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Mister Rogers. A laugh escapes from Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: As in, the hokey kid’s show guy?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: As in the beloved children’s television host, yes. Look, I think this could be good for you. Start to change your image.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t need to change my image.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Lloyd absorbs the indignity.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: He was the only person on our list willing to be interviewed by you, Lloyd. You're developing a reputation.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: A reputation? People love talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yes, they do. Until they read what you write about them.  20.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So I’m supposed to go easy on this guy because... what? He plays with puppets for a living? Ellen sighs, done with him.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: 400 words. Play nice. Lloyd can’t believe he just lost this battle. INT. ESQUIRE MAGAZINE - LLOYD’S CUBICLE - DAY A shrine to Lloyd’s extensive travel and accomplishments. Buried in the clutter is a photo of Lloyd and Andrea and baby announcement for Gavin. Lloyd sits at his desk, stewing. He picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, this is Lloyd Vogel with Esquire Magazine calling to schedule an interview with, um -- (quietly) Mister Rogers? One of Lloyd’s peers walks by, and Lloyd slinks down. EXT. LLOYD’S BUILDING - DAY Lloyd approaches his building. Jerry is waiting by his gold ‘93 CADILLAC DEVILLE. His fa is swollen and bruised too. He follows Lloyd to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Sorry about your face. I got it good, too. Lloyd doesn’t speak. He just keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I messed this up. I just want to talk to you. We have a lot that needs to be said.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. I’m not going to be ambushed. Lloyd opens the door, steps through --

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Come on, Lloyd. -- and locks it behind him. Jerry lingers on the other side of the door, wounded and embarrassed. INT. LLOYD’S LOFT - CONTINUOUS Lloyd steps out of the elevator into SCREAMING BABIES and MOMS. It’s Andrea’s “Mommy and Me” group.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Hi honey.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hi. Hi guys. The Moms turn, smile politely -- confused by Lloyd’s face

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smells in here.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s the bathroom trash. Nine kinds of diapers. Lloyd slinks into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd ties off the trash bag. He makes his way out when the phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: Fred, 40, sits behind a microphone at a hearing.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: In 1969, the US Senate considered a bill that would cut funding for the newly formed Corporation for Public Broadcasting. At stake was a grant for nearly twenty million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PASTORE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Will it make you happy if you read it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I'd just like to talk about it, if it's all right. On our program, we deal with such things as -- as the inner drama of childhood. We don't have to bop somebody over the head to make drama on the screen. We deal with such things as getting a haircut, or the feelings about brothers and sisters, and the kind of anger that arises in simple family situations. I think that it's much more dramatic that two men could be working out their feelings of anger -- much more dramatic than showing something of gunfire.  43.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PASTORE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Do you narrate it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I'm the host, yes. And I do all the puppets and I write all the music, and I write all the scripts -- Lloyd bounces Gavin, but he doesn’t look at him. He’s absorbed in the TV. Gavin fusses.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Gavin) Shhh shh. It’s okay little guy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Could I tell you the words of one of the songs, which I feel is very important?

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PASTORE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: It starts out: “What do you do with the mad that you feel?” And that first line came straight from a child. “When you feel so mad you could bite. When the whole wide world seems oh so wrong, and nothing you do seems very right. What do you do? Do you punch a bag? Do you pound some clay or some dough? Do you round up friends for a game of tag or see how fast you go? It's great to be able to stop when you've planned the thing that's wrong. And be able to do something else instead -- and think this song.” Fred is impassioned. His voice, clear and strong.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: “I can stop when I want to. Can stop when I wish. Can stop, stop, stop anytime. And what a good feeling to feel like this! And know that the feeling is really mine. Know that there's something deep inside that helps us become what we can. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: For a girl can be someday a lady, and a boy can be someday a man.” All the attention turns to Senator Pastore.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PASTORE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Well -- I'm supposed to be a pretty tough guy, and this is the first time I've had goose bumps for the last two days. The crowd laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Well, I'm grateful, not only for your goose bumps, but for your interest in -- in our kind of communication.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PASTORE, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I think it's wonderful. It's wonderful. Looks like you just earned them their twenty million dollars. The crowd applauds. Lloyd pauses the VCR, capturing Fred, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: OPRAH, at her 1980s peak, interviews Fred.

dialogues.speaker: OPRAH
dialogues.text: What do you think is the biggest mistake people make in raising their children?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Uh, not to remember their own childhood.

dialogues.speaker: OPRAH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I think that the best thing that we can do is to think about what it was like for us, and know what our children are going through.  45.

dialogues.speaker: OPRAH
dialogues.text: But you know what, it’s so hard once you get to be a parent, you always say ‘I will never do this’ when your mother is doing it to you, or your father is doing it to you, you say I will never do this to my child, and then you get to our age and you forget what it was like to be this size. You really do forget.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: But those children can help re- envoke what it was like. And that’s why when you’re a parent you have a new chance to grow.

dialogues.speaker: OPRAH
dialogues.text: You do. Did you ever -- I can’t imagine -- I know you are the father of two boys, but I can’t imagine you ever having a problem with your children. You ever have any?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Well, of course. I’m a human being just like everybody else. Lloyd stares down at Gavin, who is now sound asleep -- something wells within him. EXT. LLOYD’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd looks out the window. Jerry’s Cadillac is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The research clips continue -- but now they’re speeding u and shifting -- as if they’re worming into Lloyd’s consciousness. - Daniel the Striped Tiger sits on the Clocktower waving.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Hello, Lloyd - Fred testifies before Congress in 1969. His voice, clea and strong.  46.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I can stop when I want to. Can stop when I wish. Can stop, stop, stop anytime. And what a good feeling to feel like this! And know that the feeling is really mine. - King Friday calls from the castle.

dialogues.speaker: KING FRIDAY
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of? Distorted images float in, menacing and surreal -- - Lloyd slams the door in Jerry's face. - Fred’s crouched down, singing as Daniel. He looks up DIRECTLY AT LLOYD. - Fred takes picture and picture after picture. - Jerry appears dressed as Mr. McFeely

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Speedy Delivery! - Daniel the Striped Tiger sleeps. As he rolls over, he BECOMES Lloyd. A ringing PHONE brings us to -- INT. LLOYD’S LOFT - EARLY MORNING Lloyd and Andrea are asleep. The house phone RINGS, waking them. Andrea answers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Oh my, I woke you up. Is this Andrea?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: This is Fred Rogers. Andrea smiles, star-struck.  47.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Oh hil!

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Uh, Lloyd’s right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred’s dressed for the day.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Andrea, while I have you, I just wanted to thank you so much for sharing Lloyd with us.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Um. You’re welcome?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: It can’t be easy -- with him traveling, what with Gavin at home.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Thank you for saying that. I'll give you to Lloyd now. (to Lloyd) Mister Rogers knows my name! She hands Lloyd the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: This is Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You left without getting to say goodbye so I’m glad we get to continue to talk. I’m going to New York City today to film and Joanne is coming with me, so we thought you might like to come down and say hello.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Uh -- The sound of a STRING QUARTET takes us to --  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CREW films the Quartet as they play beautifully. Fred s on a stool nearby, listening with abandon. A bright smile his face. All the seats are empty except for Bill and Lloyd, in the back row.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: How much time will I get with him today? Bill shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You're here because Fred wants you here.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Honored.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: He likes everybody, but he loves people like you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: People like me?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’ve read your work. You don’t really care for humanity, do you?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m just doing my job.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I insisted he read you before we agreed.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: And did he?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Every article we could find. The song ends and Fred claps.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh thank you. That made me wanna get up and do a little dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered around the theater doors. Lloyd watches as Fred patiently meets everyone, listening deeply to each person. Bill is by his side.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hello everybody. Nice to see you. JOANNE, an older WOMAN with short gray hair sidles up nex Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: I call this move the handshake handoff. A WOMAN talks to Fred as he shakes her hand. Bill puts his hand on both of their hands and shakes in rhythm -- and then suddenly the Woman is shaking Bill's h as Fred moves on to the next person.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Quite a skill.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: We stole Bill from the governor’s office fourteen years ago. Have you got to know him yet?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Love Bill. Big fan.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: He’s very protective of Roge.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You call him Roge?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: We don’t call him Mister Rogers at home, dear. She puts out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Joanne Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, nice to meet you.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: You as well, dear.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: How does it feel to be married to a living saint? Joanne’s smile drops.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: I’m not fond of that term.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: If you think of him as a saint, then his way of being is unattainable. He works at it all the time. It’s a practice. He’s not a perfect person. He has a temper. He chooses how he responds to that anger.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That must take a lot of effort.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Well, he does things every day that help ground him. He reads scripture, he swims laps. He prays for people by name. Writes letters - - hundreds of them. He’s been doing that since I met him. Fred walks up.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (to Joanne) My love. He kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Bye, my love.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We'll see you in just a few hours. Fred turns his attention to Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought we might spend some time together, Lloyd.  51. Lloyd follows Fred down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors slide open. The car is filled with SCHOOL KIDS of all kinds. Fred gets on. Lloyd follows.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Do you always take the subway?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Joanne and I have a small apartment here. It’s just a few stops away. It’s the easiest way to get around sometimes. Fred sits down, and Lloyd dives in.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So -- you’ve covered some heavy stuff, especially for a show aimed at children.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I’m glad you had a chance to view our program.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Death, divorce, war. It gets dark. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You know, Lloyd -- Maggie Stewart taught me the most beautiful piece of sign language. Fred interlocks his index fingers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It means “friend.” Isn’t that perfect?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Who's Maggie Stewart? The School Kids have recognized Fred. They WHISPER. Lloyd notices, uncomfortable.  52. One KID starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: KID, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful day in the neighborhood. Then a few more join in.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: A beautiful day for a neighbor. Would you be mine? Could you be mine? Fred laughs and sings along. The entire car joins in.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It's a neighborly day in this beauty wood. A neighborly day for a beauty. Would you be mine? Could you be mine? On Lloyd, frustrated, notebook out and empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cramped and dusty. Fred and Lloyd sit uncomfortably close together -- for Ll Lloyd's recorder is out and running. A suitcase rests at Fred’s feet. Fred smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Seems like all these people line up to tell you their problems.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Isn't it wonderful? Such bravery.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Seems like that would be an incredible burden on you.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I’m grateful that you would say that, Lloyd. I’m grateful for your compassion.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Is it a burden on you?  53. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s assume it is a burden on you.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: There’s no normal life that’s free from pain.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: How do you deal with it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, there are many things you can do with your feelings that don’t hurt yourself or anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah, like what?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Why, you can pound a lump of clay. Or swim as fast as you can swim. Or play the lowest keys on the piano all together. (then)

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Do you ever talk to anyone about the burden you carry? Fred pretends to slam the keys.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM.
dialogues.text: Lloyd blinks, startled. The recorder runs with a faint electronic hiss. Fred looks up, deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like to meet my friends from The Neighborhood of Make Believe? Fred opens the suitcase, revealing several PUPPETS.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: They look like they’ve seen better days.  54.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: They've been with me quite a long time.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You ever think of swapping them out or getting new ones?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Didn't you have any special friends when you were very young, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Special friends?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Maybe a special toy, or a stuffed animal you loved very much? Even when it got ratty and well-worn, you just loved it all the more?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I’m sure I did.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Can you tell me about your special friend?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Uh -- I think I had a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Did your rabbit friend have a name?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It was just rabbit -- A real memory rushes in, dislodged from somewhere deep.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was Old Rabbit. Fred leans in.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Who gave you Old Rabbit? Lloyd glares at Fred.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: My mom.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: She must love you very much.  55.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That she did. She died when I was young.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I’m sure that if she saw you today, saw the person you have become, she’d be proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I wanna get back to my questions.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You wanted to meet my special friends from the Neighborhood of Make Believe.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. I asked about the burden you carry.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Let’s see -- Fred scans his puppets one by one, choosing his weapon carefully. First is the King Friday puppet. Fred does his voice, deep and majestic.

dialogues.speaker: KING FRIDAY
dialogues.text: I am King Friday the thirteenth. Lloyd Vogel the journalist, I presume. Lloyd stares blankly at the puppet. Fred picks up Daniel Striped Tiger.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (in his own voice) And here's Daniel Striped Tiger. He’s often too shy to talk. (to Daniel) But that’s all right Daniel. (to Lloyd) Have you met Daniel? Fred moves closer to Lloyd, sitting right next to him.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. Not officially. Daniel turns to Lloyd.  56. Fred speaks in Daniel’s high, sweet voice.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I'd like to meet Old Rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Fred) I don’t want to talk about Old Rabbit, I gotta say.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (to Daniel) Maybe Lloyd doesn’t want to talk right now, Daniel. And that’s okay. Daniel hangs his head.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Can you put the puppet down? Fred obliges.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What else would you like to discuss, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You stopped making the show for three years in the mid-seventies. Why did you quit?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: At the time, I felt like the program had covered the main facets of childhood.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: And what brought you back? Money? Boredom?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: My sons had grown into teenagers. And were struggling. We all were. I realized there was still much more to talk about. Lloyd leans in. Finally something he can use.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine it was easy to grow up with you as a father.  57.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Until recently, my eldest never told people about me. He’s very private, and that’s okay. My younger son -- he genuinely tested me -- but eventually we found our way. I’m so proud of them both. (then) But you’re right, Lloyd -- it couldn’t have been easy on them. Thank you. Thank you for that perspective. Lloyd sighs, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Fred waits patiently for the next question. Lloyd burns.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Was that not the answer you were looking for? Being a parent doesn’t mean being a perfect parent. You might be experiencing some of that now, with your son? Lloyd and Fred stare at each other for an uncomfortable moment.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, I've been thinking a great deal about you and your father. Were you able to work through your disagreement?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. Lloyd gets up.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: We're done. Thanks. It’s been a real pleasure. Lloyd walks out.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Mercy.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd walks home, a mess. He scans the street for Jerry’s car, doesn’t see it. What a relief. INT. LLOYD’S LOFT - DAY Lloyd enters. Jerry sits at the table next to Andrea. Behind them stands DOROTHY, holding Gavin. We recognize h from the wedding, but now she’s dressed down, natural. There’s food on the table.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Hey hey. Lloyd drops his bag and keys, furious.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon, sit down. We cooked you some take-out.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: They brought pizza. Andrea pleads to Lloyd with her eyes. Just sit down.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Lloyd, this is Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Hello. Lloyd won’t look at Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Can’t you just say hello? Where’s your manners?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. We should just go. Dorothy hands Gavin to Andrea.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: (to Lloyd) I had an idea, okay? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'd eat some food, and we’d talk like people. I messed things up at the wedding -- Lloyd says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, you didn’t help, but I get it. Jerry's anger’s burbling up, getting the better of him.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then you let me sit out there in my car on the street. For two nights. Like I’m homeless, like I’m a bum --

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (to Jerry) You're not helping.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: What’s the point? He won’t say a word. Finally, Lloyd looks at Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You came here to introduce me to her, right?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Dorothy. Lloyd turns to Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hi, Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Hello, Lloyd. Dorothy says nothing. Lloyd turns back to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay, you did what you came here to do. Now I want you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Lloyd --  60.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I might never come back here, so please listen to me. Dorothy and I have been together and in love for fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Dorothy) He left as soon as Mom got sick. Did you know that? He couldn’t even wait for her to die.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: She really didn’t want me there.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Because you were sleeping around while she was dying.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I know. It took me years to get myself together. Dorothy is why I’m standing here. She helped me grow the hell up. Andrea's eyes well. Lloyd just stares, then turns to Doro

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You know what they tell you about people dying? They tell you it’s peaceful. They just slip away. Mom screamed as she went. You know that? She screamed until she passed out and then they came in and revived her and she went right back to it. Jerry's hand goes to his face -- he massages his jaw --

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Lloyd --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It was me and Lorraine and the nurses! Sign the paperwork. Put her in the ground. Pack up the house.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Hang on -- can we -- Jerry kneads his thumb into his jaw. Beads of sweat form his forehead.  61.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My jaw -- Jerry SLUMPS forward in his chair, head HITTING the table Plates CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Jerry. JERRY! Dorothy grabs Jerry. Andrea's at the phone, dialing 911. Lloyd stands there, staring at Jerry, eyes wide. Complete frozen. He looks over at Andrea, talking hurriedly into the phone He looks at Dorothy, pushing Jerry upright, slapping his face.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Lloyd, do something! Jerry crumples to the floor, unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd waits just outside Jerry’s room. He hears the DOCTO talking to Jerry and Dorothy, who’s crying. It’s a blur o words.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: The cardiac MRI revealed more extensive stenosis than we thought... An operation at this time... The risk of infection alone... At your age... It’s not much of a conversation anymore... we knew we’d be here...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I’m just supposed to go home?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There are many options. Your home is one of them... I’1l have someone from hospice come in to walk you through it... Lloyd walks down the hall, emotionally crumbling. He PUSH through the door and into the --  62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty, except for Andrea and Gavin, asleep in his car sea

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You know anything? Lloyd sits down, unable to answer. His heart is racing. H sweating.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I hate hospitals. Andrea puts her hand on the back of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should go home. Get him to bed.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to leave you here. Lloyd tries to calm himself, but something’s not right. P is growing, clouding his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m not staying here.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Okay. Let’s all go together.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. I have to go to Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I have to work.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: With your dad like this?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I have a deadline.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I’m pretty sure Ellen will understand if you tell her what’s happening.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. I want to go to Pittsburgh. I want to do my job. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This shouldn’t be a surprise to you. Lloyd walks toward the door. Andrea moves to block him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to me like that.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You seem to think that now that we have a kid, I shouldn’t care about things I have always cared about, just because you don’t anymore. Well, I still care about my work.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I never asked you to stop caring about your work.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Why? Everyone who is important is in this hospital right now.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Can’t you be on my side for once? You used to be on my side.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I’m telling you -- because I amon your side, because I love you -- NoW is not the time to go work. A MAN passes in front of Lloyd. He looks like Fred -- and he’s carrying a bag with DANIEL TIGER peeking out. Lloyd blinks. Was that Fred? Was that real?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I -- I need to go -- if I’m going to make it to Pittsburgh by the morning. Lloyd leaves, following the Man.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Fine. I’m gonna go sit with your family, while you go.  64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd rushes out of the hospital, avoiding an ambulance a stretcher on his way, his heart beating quickly, looking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd spots the Man with Daniel Tiger in his bag and foll him through the crowd -- through the maze of the bus term -- up escalators, and finally outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busses idle. Lloyd scans until -- He SPOTS the Man getting on a bus -- The destination: PITTSBURGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd races onto the bus, looking at the PASSENGERS. No Fred. The bus pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: MINIATURE PITTSBURGH
dialogues.text: The sun rises behind the skyline of Pittsburgh, the light reflecting off the buildings, the river. A BUS zooms over a bridge as the sun rises behind the skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd hurries up to a WQED -- everything looks normal but clouds might be made of COTTON. And -- is the building ma of BALSAWOOD?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd rushes into the stage to find Margy and the rest of crew setting up for an episode.

dialogues.speaker: MARGY
dialogues.text: Lloyd. There you are.  65.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I need to talk to Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MARGY
dialogues.text: very funny, mister. Get over there. We're ready to shoot. The First AD pushes Lloyd toward the lit set.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AD
dialogues.text: Right this way.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AD
dialogues.text: You're in this episode, of course. Wait over there. Vibraphone music chimes in. The First AD points Lloyd toward the front door of the se

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sound speed.

dialogues.speaker: SOUND GUY
dialogues.text: Speed.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AD
dialogues.text: And.... Action. Lloyd stands outside of the door. The First AD signals for him to KNOCK. He does. Fred opens the door, to a shell-shocked Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Why, it’s my good friend, Lloyd Vogel. (to the camera) You remember Lloyd. Lloyd steps onto the familiar landing of the familiar set

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Fred -- I don’t understand. (then, looking out) Can we stop?  66.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Are you feeling unwell, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop asking me questions. I ask you the questions.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: On today’s program I thought we would talk about hospitals. Fred looks out to the cameras. And we --

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes when someone is sick, they have to visit the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I hate hospitals.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: A hospital is a place where doctors and nurses work together to take special care of people who are sick or hurt.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Would you like to pretend we’re at a hospital, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd pulls back a curtain and peeks out. He’s on the CASTLE SET and he’s SMALL. The size of a pupp He takes a step out. The Trolley comes ROARING up to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOOT TOOT
dialogues.text: X The Owl appears in his tree.  67.

dialogues.speaker: X THE OWL
dialogues.text: Hello, Old Rabbit. Suddenly, Lloyd has TWO RABBIT EARS. He tugs at them. The firmly attached to his skull. King Friday appears in a parapet.

dialogues.speaker: KING FRIDAY
dialogues.text: Old Rabbit, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m not -- I don’t -- Where’s Fred? Lloyd starts breathing hard. Daniel appears next to Lloyd

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I've been waiting to meet you, Old Rabbit. I’m so happy you came for a visit. Lloyd looks down and sees Fred down below the set, his ha in the puppet.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, Lady Aberlin. Andrea appears, dressed as Lady Aberlin.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Well hello. Hello, Old Rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: KING FRIDAY
dialogues.text: We were discussing hospitals.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Well, a hospital is where you go when your body is hurt, but what do you do when your feelings are hurt? A piano riff wafts in...

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: Well, you talk about them.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: You talk about them.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It’s good to talk. It’s good to say the things we feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s happening to me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It’s good to talk. We’re much more real without the lock. Fred steps out from behind the set.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It’s good to talk. He looks at Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Try saying “I like you.” They all look at Lloyd. We hold for a painfully long beat, until --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Andrea) I like you.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I’m sad.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m sad.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I’m angry. The music stops. Lloyd pauses. He can’t.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're angry. When did you become angry? Do you remember? Did something happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd steps towards a pool of light. 68.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: At its center, Lloyd’s mother, LILA VOGEL, 45, lying ina hospital bed. She smiles when she sees him.  69.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: Hey peanut.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: LILA
dialogues.text: I know you think you're doing this for me. Holding onto this anger. I don’t need it. Lloyd begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Lloyd? INT. WQED - MISTER ROGERS’ NEIGHBORHOOD SET - DAY Lloyd lies on his back, unconscious, Fred and the Crew standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARGY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He just collapsed. A Schumann PIANO DUET starts with a jolt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd springs up from a deep sleep, disoriented. The piano is coming from the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd ambles through slowly. He notices pictures hanging along walls. REAL PEOPLE, all races, genders, ages, abilities. All smiling. These are Fred’s friends.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spacious and well appointed, but not showy in the least. room is dominated by two GRAND PIANOS. Joanne sits at the piano closest to the window playing effortlessly, her fingers light on the keys. Fred, sits at the other, not quite as good, but heartfelt and keeping up. Lloyd wanders in. Listens.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Turn. They both turn their sheet music and continue, until -- Fred spots Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (to Lloyd) Oh good, you’re awake.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Goodness, if I knew you were there, I would have stopped all the racket.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No, no. That was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You must be very hungry. Let me get my jacket, and we'll go out.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Fred walks down the hallway. Lloyd stares at Joanne -- not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: You're really in it, mister. Fred walks back in with his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: How about some Chinese food? I love those spring rolls.  71.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Sure. As they go --

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE
dialogues.text: Tell Andrea and Gavin I say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hole in the wall. TWO COUPLES and a SMALL FAMILY eat beside Fred and Lloyd. The WAITRESS sets down their food. Fred's plate is piled high with vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, look at that. Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You a vegetarian? Lloyd bites into an egg roll.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I just can’t imagine eating anything with a mother. Lloyd laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Bill was right. You love people like me.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What are people like you? Lloyd is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve never met anyone like you in my entire life.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Broken people.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I don’t think you are broken. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are a man of conviction, a person who knows what is wrong and what is right. (then) Try to remember that your relationship with your father also helped to shape those parts. He helped you become who you are. Lloyd shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you do something with me, Lloyd? A little exercise I like to do sometimes. Lloyd glances around -- everyone’s staring and leaning 72. in. Fred notices, but rather than whisper, he speaks a little louder.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll take a minute and think about all the people who... loved us into being.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: They will come to you. Lloyd takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just one minute of silence. Fred looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's begin. As the minute passes -- Lloyd sniffs. He sniffs again. We realize that the whole restaurant is quiet. They’re doing it. And suddenly, Fred is looking DIRECTLY INTO CAMERA and his gaze, effortlessly. all holds  73. Now Lloyd's eyes are welling. His face contorts as the emotions build. For once, finally, Lloyd experiences a brief moment of clarity.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for doing that with me. I feel so much better. Lloyd smiles through his tears. He knows what he has to d

dialogues.speaker: MINIATURE NYC AIRPORT
dialogues.text: A tiny plane touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd walks with Andrea, who holds a sleeping Gavin in a wrap. She’s still angry with him.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So the way I left --

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Was messed up.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes. I should’ve called you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t have left. (then) The doctor came out looking for you and I didn’t know what to tell her -- I didn’t know what to tell your dad. And of course I couldn’t get a cab, so I took a train. At midnight. The way people were looking at me with Gavin. I was like ‘somebody's calling child services.’ Lloyd looks down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you’re trying to apologize, but that doesn’t mean it gets to be easy. They both smile. Andrea exhales.  74.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I realize now -- that I need to deal with my -- feelings. On Andrea, did he say feelings?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I’m scared -- which I was in the hospital and have been for a long time, I guess -- I just get really angry.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Mmhmm. Lloyd fights for the words, struggling.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: And -- I know, it’s a way of saying I can’t deal with this -- leave me alone. And that’s not what I want. Lloyd holds back tears.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the opposite of what I actually want. You and Gavin are -- I don’t want to push you away. You’re what I want. Andrea tears up. Lloyd holds her. They both cry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. (then) I need to go see Jerry. He's... dying. Saying it is hard.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred kneels, praying beside his bed.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Celia Sherman. Colby Dickerson --  75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church-like silence hangs over the Olympic sized pool. The water is completely still, like glass. Fred steps to the edge, in his Speed-o and swim cap. He f his goggles into place.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Justin Cook. He dives in. His movements are smooth. His arms knife through the wate feet churning behind him. He reaches the edge and then kicks off -- WHOOSH -- glidi back to where he started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back of a taxi, Lloyd eyes the small house with Jerry's Cadillac parked in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Lloyd Vogel. Andrea Vogel. Gavin Vogel. Jerry Vogel. Lloyd gets out, walks up the path, and rings the bell. He waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Thank you, God. Dorothy answers. She’s in a housecoat, no make up. After a long silence --

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's lying in a hospital bed, asleep. Lloyd takes a long look. Like this, Jerry looks so small old. Dorothy whispers.  76.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He’ll be so happy you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No, don’t wake him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Dorothy sip tea and poke at a plate of cheese a crackers. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: He still eats like a teenager. Cold cuts and sugar cereal. Stubborn goat. Least you come by it honestly.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Did you know about me and my sister?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Not until very recently.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What about my mom?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: When he got sick last year -- after the first episode -- he started to talk -- to tell me things I wish he’d told me a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t budge. She steps out, then comes back with a scrap book.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Everything you ever wrote. He kept it in his trunk so I wouldn’t see it. When they towed the car here, I found it. He turns the pages. Article after article. Cut out and fi  77. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - GUEST ROOM - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd sits in the sofa bed, laptop out. He’s typing furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV’s on. Jerry sits up, watching, sipping OJ through a straw. Lloy beside him.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: We got bourbon, you know. Someone should drink it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Not even beer?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Do you have a beer? Yeah, I'd drink a beer if it made you happy.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: No. I don’t have a beer. And don’t do it because it’d make me happy. Do it cause you wanna do it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You don’t have a beer and I don’t want a beer.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: So don’t drink anything. Dehydrate. After a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m trying.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No, I’m trying. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t like alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Because I drink?  78.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Probably. (then) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, you are some pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t like Cadillacs either.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You're gonna give me another heart attack. Both men crack a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd lifts luggage out of the trunk while Andrea waits w Gavin. He kisses

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I definitely broke the pack n’ play. It just snapped like a chicken bone. (then) How is he?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: He seems fine, but I don’t know. They don’t put a hospital bed in your living room if you’re fine. (then) Thank you for coming. her.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re gonna love the sofa bed.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - GUEST BEDROOM - LATE NIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Andrea are asleep. Gavin cries.  79. Lloyd gets up, and takes Gavin into -- INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - LATE NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd holds Gavin in one arm while he pulls a bottle from fridge. He puts it in a pot with water and sets it on the stove. The only light comes from the burner.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Shhh. Shhh. As the bottle heats, Lloyd sits down with Gavin. He sways side to side.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know, you wish it was your mom who was awake right now. But we’re gonna let her sleep, okay? I’m gonna get better at this. And we're going to have to get used to each other. Slowly, quietly, only for Gavin -- Lloyd stumbles his way through the Mister Rogers song --

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: I like you as you are Exactly and precisely I think you turned out nicely Gavin begins to settle.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like you as you are Without a doubt or question -- Suddenly Lloyd realizes -- Gavin is looking right at him.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (0.C)
dialogues.text: Who’s that? Dorothy? INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd emerges with Gavin holding his bottle to find his father awake in his hospital bed.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What? Are you okay?  80.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s four in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep much these days. Jerry nods at Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t sleep either, do ya? (then) I never did this with you. Up in the middle of the night, doing the mom thing.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s not a mom thing.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. The moment hangs.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You should rest.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: No, stay. Lloyd puts Gavin in the car seat, and sits next to Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, right back there.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What? Jerry nods toward a side table.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Grab two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t think that’s the best idea.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: How do you know? You don’t drink. (then) Come on.  81.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Fine. Lloyd pours two glasses -- a thimble in his own.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Now we're talking.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Cheers. They clink. Lloyd takes a drink and coughs. Jerry laughs. The moment hangs, then --

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Lloyd -- Jerry inhales.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I left you and your sister. It was selfish. And it was - - cruel. Lloyd looks at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you look at me? Lloyd looks at Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am so sorry, son. Lloyd and Jerry sit in silence, until --

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not fair, you know? I think I’m just now starting to figure out how to live my life. Jerry's eyes pool with tears.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve always loved you. Lloyd smiles through his tears, takes his father’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I love you too, Dad. Lloyd looks directly at his father, really seeing him.  82. Gavin stirs. Lloyd picks him up and brings him to Jerry. Jerry grabs Gavin's toe. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - SUN ROOM - DAY Lloyd paces, bouncing Gavin, while Andrea reads a draft o Lloyd's article. She makes a noise.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s stupid.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Shhhh! Finally, Andrea finishes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like ten thousand words.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: And it’s not really about Mister Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I mean it is, but it’s -- so YOU. You never talk about this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No. Andrea smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: It’s good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Yeah. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - GUEST ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Lloyd. 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. ESQUIRE MAGAZINE - ELLEN’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen talks at her desk, almost annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I love it. Lloyd's face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s going to be the cover. Don’t tell anyone I told you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t deserve you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: No you don’t. She hangs up.
