dialogues.text: Esquire Magazine gets printed. The cover -- a disarming, smiling portrait of Fred in his cardigan. The title reads -- CAN YOU SAY... HERO? The magazines are boxed and loaded onto trucks.  84. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry reads Lloyd's article in Esquire, a stack of them a by the front door. Lloyd sits beside him, looking on nervously. Jerry snorts. Lloyd smiles. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd hugs Lorraine and Todd by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay right off the bat -- about the wedding --

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Whatever. It was the most entertaining one yet. (then) I’m just glad you’re here. Lorraine heads inside, leaving Todd and Lloyd facing off. Lloyd puts his hand out. A peace offering. Todd slaps him on the shoulder and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd, Andrea, Lorraine, Todd, and Dorothy have gathered around Jerry's bed. He’s more gaunt now, and his color ha changed. He’s not eating anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Lorraine) Don’t go to Martha’s Vineyard.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Why not? It’s my honeymoon. I deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Absolutely you do.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s not a question of entitlement. You’re not gonna like it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a buncha rich jerks and it’ll be freezing. You’re gonna freeze to death with rich jerks. There’s a knock on the door. Lloyd springs up.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Who’s here? Lloyd opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Ah, I'm in the right place. Lloyd. Lloyd returns with Fred carrying a pie, everyone freezes.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: Holy crap. Fred laughs. Andrea rises, receives the pie.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Andrea?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Hello Fred.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Its such a pleasure to finally see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (re: pie) Can I take this for you?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. Everyone is wide eyed, frozen, taking in the celebrity in their house.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Hello, Mister Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hello. Lorraine nudges him.  86. Fred leans over to Gavin.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And hello Gavin, I hope you and I can be friends someday. Fred approaches Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mister Vogel, may I call you Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Yes sir, you certainly may. He reaches out and shakes Jerry’s hand, who is touched. INT. JERRY AND DOROTHY’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - LATER Fred and the Vogels eat pie. They sit on couches and chai around Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Lloyd, Joanne adored your article. As did I.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m so glad.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Andrea, are you feeling more ready about daycare?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: A little. Maybe. Lloyd gives Andrea a look.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? You’re not the only one who talks to Fred.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: Hey Mister Rogers, is it true you were a sharp shooter?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: A Navy Seal!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: No, I’m afraid not.  87.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: What kind of an insane question is that?

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: I heard it.

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: (to Andrea) Where did you guys go on your honeymoon?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: We eloped in Maui, so we were kinda already on our honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: I woulda gone.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You weren’t invited.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Lloyd’s embarrassed by us. Lloyd bristles a bit.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Maybe we do a family vacation instead. What do you think, Dad? Should we dip our toes in the ocean together?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY
dialogues.text: I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Crash your honeymoon? Count me in. If I’m still here. Lloyd, Andrea, and Todd look at their plates, uncomfortab Nobody is saying what they’re actually thinking. Fred smiles.  88.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You know, death is something that many of us are uncomfortable speaking about. But, to die is to be human. And anything human is mentionable, and anything that is mentionable is manageable. Lorraine looks at Jerry, tears forming.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything mentionable is manageable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred's got his camera out, and the family is standing together around Jerry's bed.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You gotta send me a copy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Joanne will be so happy to see this.

dialogues.speaker: TODD
dialogues.text: It'd be so much cooler if he were in it.

dialogues.speaker: LORRAINE
dialogues.text: Shhh. Fred snaps the photo.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Thank you. (then) I should be going.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’1l1 walk you out. Fred kneels down, incredibly close to Jerry, and whispers something to him.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You can count on it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Thank you.  89.

dialogues.text: Fred and Lloyd walk to the curb where Bill waits with a T CAR.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hey -- what did you say to Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I asked him to pray for me.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: For you?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I figure anyone who’s going through what he’s going through must be awfully close to God. Fred gets into his seat. Bill shuts the door.

dialogues.text: Lloyd.

dialogues.text: Bill.

dialogues.text: Fred sits on a grassy patch next to a house. He talks to camera, slow and introspective.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: When I was very young I had a dog that I loved very much. Her name was Mitzi. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And she got to be old, and she died. I was very sad when she died, because she and I were good pals. And when she died, I cried. And my grandmother heard me crying, I remember, and she came and just put her arm around me, because she knew I was sad. She knew how much I loved that dog. And my dad said we'd have to bury Mitzi, and I didn't want to. I didn't want to bury her because I thought I’d just pretend that she was still alive. But my dad said that her body was dead and we'd have to bury her. So we did. Soft music starts.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes people get sad and they really do feel bad, but the very same people who are sad sometimes are the very same people who are glad sometimes.

dialogues.text: It’s funny but it’s true It's the same, isn't it for me and - We push into --

dialogues.text: Lloyd, Andrea, Dorothy, Lorraine and Todd are gathered ar Jerry's casket, as the PRIEST prays.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Sometimes people are good And they do just what they should But the very same people who are good sometimes Are the very same people who are bad sometimes  91. The prayer ends. Everyone stands, sharing a hug or a supportive arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the guests trickle off, Andrea finds Lloyd with Gavin wrap on his chest. She holds a bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It's funny, but it's true It’s the same isn’t it, for me Isn’t it the same for you? Lloyd and Andrea walk together, through the stones.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You know -- maybe I can slow down for a few months.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Stay home with Gavin. Let you get back to work, without worrying about daycare. I want to. Andrea folds into Lloyd as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Really? You? Lloyd nods.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Gavin and I already discussed and we both agree. Andrea takes Lloyd’s arm. They walk down the path, togeth A PIANO TRILL takes us back to --

dialogues.text: Welcome back, neighbor. I hope you know that you've made this day a special day, by just your being you. dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l show it to you. Fred takes out a PHOTO. On a SUNNY BEACH -- Lloyd, Andrea, Lorraine and Todd hudd around Dorothy, smiling big. She holds Gavin, who clutche OLD RABBIT in his tiny hands.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s a nice picture.

dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: You're growing inside. And when you wake up ready to say... He stands and unzips his Red Cardigan, then moves to the closet and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: "I think I'll make a snappy new day." Fred snaps twice, once with each hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: It's such a good feeling, a very good feeling, the feeling you know that I'll be back when the week is new. He carefully hangs up the sweater, then pulls his gray sp coat off a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: And I'll have more ideas for you. And you'll have things you'll want to talk about. I will too. He grabs the board with windows on it from the bench.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be back next time. He waves and moves toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bye bye. He goes, smiling.
